titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Riggs Family records (Page R. Bradley donation), 1800-1950 MS2336
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-01-18 12:02:47 -0500.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.unittitle: Riggs Family records (Page R. Bradley donation)

physdesc.extent: Collection contains 2 record center boxes, 4 flat boxes, and 1 slim document box.

did.abstract: This collection contains materials relating to the Riggs family, a prominent family in the Washington, D.C. area notable for its banking fame. The materials in this collection include business ledgers, correspondence, and personal belongings related to various members of the Riggs family. These materials date from the early 1800s to 1950. The most notable members of the Riggs family represented in this collection are: Elisha Riggs (New York merchant & Georgetown business man), George Washington Riggs (head of Riggs' banking business, known as "The President's Banker"), Elisha Francis Riggs (successor to G.W. Riggs in banking firm), Thomas Riggs, Jr. (Governor of Alaska Territory & U.S. Commissioner to the International Boundary Commission), and Thomas Lawrason Riggs (first Catholic chaplain of Yale University & musical theatre lyricist).

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Riggs family, notable for its banking fame, was prominent in the Washington, D.C. area in the 19th and 20th century. The earliest incarnation of Riggs Bank was formed in 1836 when William Wilson Corcoran opened a small brokerage house. In 1840, Corcoran and George Washington Riggs, the son of a neighbor, formed "Corcoran & Riggs", which offered checking and depositing services. The bank got a major boost in 1844, when The U.S. government assigned Corcoran & Riggs to be the only federal depository in Washington. In 1854 Corcoran retired, and the bank changed its name to "Riggs & Co." After accepting a government charter, "Riggs National Bank" was born in 1896. By 1900, Riggs was twice as large as any other bank in D.C. It embarked on a successful project to become known as the bank of embassies and diplomats, and by 1950 most embassies in Washington were customers. Many branches thereafter opened within embassies in Washington D.C. and London. Riggs Bank was bought by PNC for $779 million in 2005.

The most notable members of the Riggs family represented in this collection are: Elisha Riggs (New York merchant & Georgetown business man), George Washington Riggs (head of Riggs' banking business, known as "The President's Banker"), Elisha Francis Riggs (successor to G.W. Riggs in banking firm), Thomas Riggs, Jr. (Governor of Alaska Territory & U.S. Commissioner to the International Boundary Commission), and Thomas Lawrason Riggs (first Catholic chaplain of Yale University & musical theatre lyricist).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials in this collection include business ledgers, correspondence, and personal belongings related to various members of the Riggs family. These materials date from the early 1800s to 1950.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into 3 series: Business ledgers, Correspondence, and Personal artifacts.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Page R. Bradley, 9 March 2015 [2015.019]

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains 3 business ledgers dating from 1826 to 1851. The material relates to the businesses of the Riggs family, including Riggs and Levering and Elisha Riggs & Sons. Material also includes estate records of Samuel Lukens.

did.physdesc: 26 pages with text and 12 additional pages showing text cut out. No company name identified. "ESTATE" imprinted on cover. "Sam'l Lukens" written on front and inside cover. (1/4 leather, quarto). Fragile and worn from age and use.

did.unittitle: Ledger/receipt book for Elisha Riggs and Sons, St. Louis and New York
did.physdesc: 125 pages including 3 pages of index. (Full leather, quarto). Fragile and worn from age and use.

did.unittitle: Ledger/receipt book for Riggs and Levering, New York City
did.physdesc: 350 pages containing 12 pages of an alphabetical index and 340 pages of text entries. (1/4 leather, quarto). Fragile and worn from age and use.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence with the Riggs family. This material dates from 1826 to 1939. Writers and recipients include: Elisha Riggs, Thomas Riggs, Medora Riggs, Mary R.L. McCullough, A. Bowie Davis, George W. Howard, and George Dewey.

did.unittitle: Letter: Elisha Riggs to brother Thomas Riggs
Letter: A. Bowie Davis to George W. Howard
did.physdesc: 6 pages; regarding the life of the late Elisha Riggs

did.unittitle: Letter: George Dewey to Mrs. Medora Riggs
did.physdesc: 1 page; on Admiral of the Navy stationary

did.unittitle: Letter: Mary R.L. McCullough to Thomas Riggs
Letter: Mary R.L. McCullough to Thomas Riggs
Letter: Mary R.L. McCullough to Thomas Riggs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of various items belonging to members of the Riggs family. Personalized objects include: sheet music, daguerreotypes, fine china, serving dishes, miniature paintings, cuff links, dress pins, card cases, hair ornaments, shoe ornaments, napkin rings, lapel pins, medallions, pendants, buttoniers, cigarette cases, office supplies, a whistle pendant, a ceramic fish, and a woodblock stamp. The objects range in date from the mid-1800s to 1950. Owners of the objects include: Thomas Lawrason Riggs, C.F. Riggs, Elisha Francis Riggs, B.F. Riggs, F.E. Riggs, F.L. Riggs, H. Riggs, Lawrason Riggs, Miss J.R. Shedden, Amelia J. Riggs, George Washington Riggs, Samuel J. Riggs, Mary Ann (Karrick) Riggs, Joseph Riggs, and Karrick Riggs.

odd.head: General Physical Description note
odd.p: 19th century sterling silver napkin ring.

odd.head: General Physical Description note
odd.p: American Legion buttonier from B.F. Riggs' jewelry box.

Man's wooden jewelry box, with remnants of dried black leather on wood; "B.F. Riggs" engraved on lid; contained 7 buttoniers, small ceramic fish, empty pencil case, empty leather bag, 14 carat fraternity pin (1"L x 5/8"W) engraved on back "T.L. Riggs," a gold pendant with image of Moliere on front and "L. Riggs" engraved on back, and Yale Drama pendant with "T.L. Riggs" engraved on back

odd.head: General Physical Description note
odd.p: Documentation about the Man's Jewelry Box. The box itself was in poor shape due to age and insect damage, therefore it was not saved. The contents were removed and cataloged individually.

odd.head: General Physical Description note
odd.p: Personalized beer stein lid made of silver metal and ceramic. Metal handle has small figure of bearded man with a pint. Ceramic inlay has colored image of dogs carrying arrows and the phrase "RECTE AGE NIL TIME." Printed on the reverse side of ceramic inlay: Karrick Van Zandt [/] Riggs [/] Hannover 1873" Ceramic is cracked in two places.

did.unittitle: Watercolor miniature painting of Samuel J. Riggs

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Note on Envelope:

Miniature of Samuel J. Riggs [/] (1811-1847) [/] son of Romulus and Mercy Ann [/] (Lawrason) Riggs of Philadelphia. [/] Painted in Paris in 1833. This picture [/] was damaged by Samuel Kirk & Son of Balt(imore) in [/] forcing it into frame, cracked across the face - for which I made them pay me $500.00
